awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Dynamics of the Milky Way's Local Group Substructure as the Key to Understanding Dark Matter and Galaxy Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
There is overwhelming astrophysical evidence that less than 5 percent of the universe is made from ordinary - or baryonic - matter. The rest of the cosmos appears to be constituted from "dark matter," which has the gravitational properties of matter but which hardly interacts with light (25 percent), together with "dark energy," which acts to repel the force of gravity. Astrophysicists have further developed this model into one in which dark matter takes the form of slow-moving particles, and dark energy is associated with a "cosmological constant" first introduced by Einstein. The model has had remarkable successes in explaining many of the observed characteristics of the universe. Nonetheless, there remain mismatches between the model and the observed properties of our own Milky Way galaxy and its neighbors. The work supported by this CAREER award will use the Gemini Observatory, of which the NSF is a founding partner, to tackle these fundamental problems and provide new constraints on the nature of dark matter. The PI, Dr. Nitya Kallivayalil, will also launch and lead a major collaboration with Spelman College, America's oldest historically Black college for women to create a pipeline for training future STEM leaders from under-represented groups.

The specific goals of the PI's program are to use the world-leading adaptive optics technologies employed by the Gemini Observatory, together with its innovative large and long observing programs, to measure the 6-dimensional phase space of tracers of the Milky Way's gravitational potential. This requires accurate proper motions, in addition to radial velocities for field stars and satellites widely distributed throughout the halo. The PI will definitively constrain the dark-halo shape, orientation, radial profile and total mass of the Milky Way; determine the infall times of its satellite galaxies; and constrain the central density distributions of dwarf galaxies to assess whether they have cusp- or core-like profiles. Furthermore, the PI's partnership with Spelman College will involve a Research Experiences for Undergraduates REU program for Spelman students, as well as curriculum development at the college.

por.por_cntn:
The dominant theory to understand the universe, the concordance dark energy plus cold dark matter (CDM) paradigm, works impressively well at large scales. However, it faces formidable challenges on small scales, such as those probed by the Local Group of galaxies. For example, a better estimate of the total halo mass is important for deciding if the Milky Way has the expected number of massive satellites or has too few of them. The most reliable means by which to constrain the properties of the Milky Way dark halo is through assessing the 6-D phase space distributions of tracers of its gravitational potential. This requires accurate proper motions (PMs) in addition to (generally known) radial velocities for field stars and satellites widely distributed throughout the halo. The purpose of this CAREER proposal is to develop methods to measure PMs for a wide variety of tracers in the Local Group.

The award has resulted in 32 publications of which we highlight a few. According to CDM theory, hierarchical evolution should occur on all mass scales, implying that satellites of the Milky Way also should have companions. In Kallivayalil et al. (2018) we show that a subset of the recently-discovered ultra-faint galaxies have come in with the Magellanic Cloud system, constituting the first confirmation of the type of satellite infall predicted by CDM theory. To do this we measured PMs for these galaxies using Gaia data and compared the resulting 3D velocities and positions to those expected for debris from an analog Magellanic system in a high resolution cosmological simulation. We also develop Adaptive Optics (AO) methods to measure PMs. In Fritz, Linden, Zivick, Kallivayalil et al. (2017) for the first time we use AO data outside dense environments to measure the absolute motion of a distant halo globular cluster, Pyxis. Based on the proper motion, we are also able to do a thorough investigation of its origins, finding it was likely donated to the Milky Way by an unknown galaxy, which today is fully disrupted. We are also able to use its orbit to place a lower limit on Milky Way mass.

In summary we have investigated a number of techniques to measure PMs, including using large format ground-based imagers, AO-based imagers, space telescopes such as Gaia and the Hubble Space Telescope, and ways to combine data from multiple telescopes (e.g., AO and HST data). These datasets have allowed us to investigate the shape of the Milky Way halo using tidal streams; calculate orbits for dwarf galaxies out to Andromeda distance which has allowed us to investigate the nature of satellite planes and group infall; and measure star formation histories for ultra-faint dwarf galaxies which has allowed us to begin to understand the impact of the physics of environment and the epoch of reionization on dwarf galaxies. Detailed mapping of PMs across the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds, using various different datasets, has also allowed us to study galaxy collisions and their impact on the galaxies involved including their star formation, morphology and state of tidal disruption, with mounting evidence that the Small Magellanic Cloud has had a direct rather than grazing collision with the Large Magellanic Cloud.

The educational component of this program was focused on a long-term collaboration with the Spelman College Physics Department in order to build a pipeline for training future STEM leaders from under-represented groups. Dr. Maeng from the Curry School assessed the impact of these research experiences over the past five years, quoting in her report that: "Overall, students participating in the REU program reported positive outcomes in terms of content knowledge, skills (e.g., conducting research, networking, communicating), knowledge of research, and knowledge of graduate school. They found the faculty and graduate students they worked with to be supportive, reassuring, and inspiring. All of the students reported that the experience met or exceeded their expectations and found the experience to be extremely positive. For many of these students, this was their first formal research experience. The results are encouraging in terms of the REU students' stated graduate school and career goals following the program, as most indicated an intention to continue in STEM at the end of the program. The goal of the Broader Impacts proposed by PI Kallivayalil was to introduce, support, and encourage women to remain in the STEM pipeline. The data suggests that the REU program as implemented was successful in providing the students that participated with the knowledge, skills, and agency and social capital to do so."
